Hey there head squeezers, its world space
week this week which is the perfect opportunity

for me to answer a question sent in on YouTube
from Patanegan which is Why do stars twinkle?

Lovely question I actually remember dancing
around the Christmas tree singing twinkle

twinkle little star over and over again at
my poor mum and dad at Christmas... that was
not last year Tom!
No!

And the scientific term for this is astronomical
scintillation.

And it's all down to the earth's atmosphere
so, above the surface of the earth you've

got loads and loads of layers of atmosphere
constantly moving pockets of warm and cold
air.

So when the light from a star travels down
through those pockets of atmosphere it refracts,

it bends and it falls on your eye and it look
like the star is moving and that's what makes

it twinkle; perfect for a nice romantic evening
stroll.

But if you were to go for a nice evening stroll
on the moon where there isn't any atmosphere
the stars wouldn't twinkle.

Good fact, which raises an interesting question
how come the moon and the planets don't twinkle?

Well stars even though they are millions miles
across are a long way away from us.

The moon is a lot closer as are most of the
other planets and that means they don't have

as much as the turbulent atmosphere for their
light to go through before it reaches their
eyes.

Of course it does go through a little of that,
it does refract slightly but not enough.

Our eyes put those images together and we
see those as perfect discs.
